title: 106_hr2720
content: The "Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 1999" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. It provides general authority for capitalization grants and outlines agreements for such grants. The "Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 1999" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act by updating requirements for construction of treatment works and providing guidance for small systems to obtain assistance. The Administrator will publish a manual to help small systems get assistance under the Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 1999, defining a small system as serving a population of 20,000 or less. SEC. 4. WATER POLLUTION CONTROL REVOLVING FUNDS. Activities eligible for assistance under the water pollution control revolving fund include construction of treatment works, lake protection programs, and management programs to improve or protect water quality of navigable waters. The water pollution control revolving fund of a State includes activities such as implementing conservation and management plans, restoring riparian areas, improving public water use efficiency, preventing water pollution, and acquiring lands for mitigation requirements related to treatment works construction. The fund balance is available indefinitely for financial assistance. Repayment period extended for disadvantaged communities to 40 years or project life. Loan guarantees for innovative technology included. Loan guarantees for innovative technology and administrative expenses are amended to provide loan guarantees for similar revolving funds and developing innovative technologies. Technical and planning assistance for small systems is also amended. Loan guarantees for innovative technology and administrative expenses are amended to provide loan guarantees for similar revolving funds and developing innovative technologies. Technical and planning assistance for small systems is also amended to include assistance in financial management, user fee analysis, budgeting, capital improvement planning, facility operation and maintenance, repair schedules, and other activities to improve wastewater treatment plant operations. The amendment specifies that such assistance amounts shall not exceed 2 percent of all grant awards to the fund under this title. Additionally, Section 603(f) is amended to ensure consistency with planning requirements, and Section 603(g) is amended to address construction assistance. The curr_chunk discusses the construction assistance criteria for publicly owned treatment works. It states that financial assistance can be provided if the project is on the State's priority list, regardless of its rank. Additionally, treatment works treating municipal waste water or domestic sewage are eligible for assistance. The curr_chunk introduces the possibility of negative interest rates for loans made to disadvantaged communities by States. The definition of a disadvantaged community is based on affordability criteria for sewage treatment charges. The curr_chunk discusses the location of works in accordance with guidelines established by the Administrator and States. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends Section 607 to allocate $3,000,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004.
